Steps.InstructionText:
In this guide you will learn about:
1. The step card
2. The tether
3. Some basic features
4. Using 3D objects
5. Customizing 3D objects
6. Tips on creating good guides

You can always navigate back to a previous step at any time by gazing at the back arrow, but let's move forward.

Navigate to the next step.

Guides has two modes. Operate and Author.
Operate mode is for experiencing a guide that  has already been created.
Author mode is for adding and customizing holograms on the steps of a guide.

What you're looking at right now is called the step card.

Your instruction text is displayed here.

Sometimes instruction text isn't enough. The media panel on the left can show an image.

Images are great for reference or validation.

The media panel can also play videos.
Videos are great for steps when a specific technique or procedure is required.
Gaze at the play button on the media panel to watch the video.

The step card intuitively follows you as you're doing work.

Try turning around and waiting for 2 seconds until you see the step card appear.

That's the basics of the step card.

Now let's get to know the tether...

The tether is the dotted line coming from the bottom of the step card.

It connects your instructional text to your 3D content.

Look down and follow the dotted line to the example machine.

In this step, the tether has been placed at a specific location on the example machine to indicate where work should occur.

Placing the tether helps instructions remain focused.

The tether can also be used to show you where an item is located or where to go.

Follow the dotted line to the wrench.

That's it for the tether.

Next are a few more useful features you should be aware of...

OUTLINE
Use Outline to quickly navigate to any step.

The guide outline will show you all the tasks in the current guide.
You can expand tasks to navigate to specific steps.

HOLOGRAM VISIBILITY
Once you know what a hologram is telling you it can be helpful to hide them.
Try toggling the example machine's visibility on and off with the toggle holograms button.

ANCHORING
Holograms should always be properly placed.
If the green border around your marker appears misaligned activate the anchor button to realign.

SAVE, UNDO, REDO
In Author mode, there are 3 unique buttons above the step card that allow authors to save, undo and redo changes.
These buttons are not available in Operate mode.

That's all the features you need to know!

Let's learn about using 3D objects...

Guides comes with a 3D toolkit of objects so you can start building your own guides right away.

Follow the tether to see just a few of the objects that are available to you.

Arrows are great for pointing to specific parts or to indicate a direction.

Pick from a variety of different sizes and shapes to fit any scenario.

EXAMPLE: ARROWS

"This is where the power button is located."
Use Hands from the 3D toolkit when you need to show an operator how to use their hand in a specific way.

EXAMPLE: HANDS

"Push this button to turn on the example machine."
Use Zones from the 3D toolkit to indicate an area of interest.

EXAMPLE: ZONES

"Don't put anything in this area"

Animated 3D objects add another layer of detail to the instructions.

Be thoughtful about how you combine 3D objects so the instructions remain clear.

EXAMPLE: ANIMATION

"Connect the air hose here."

Use custom 3D parts to provide operators with specific instructions or representations of your own products.

You can use the PC application to import your own custom 3D parts.

EXAMPLE: CUSTOM 3D PART

"Install this part in here."

Having the 3D toolkit to enhance step instructions is very helpful.

Let's find out how we can customize objects from the 3D toolkit to make steps even better...

Any hologram can have different styles, be resized and combined with other holograms to reinforce your instructions.

Let's look at a few examples...

Here the "avoid" style has been applied to a 3D part to communicate that you need to be cautious near it.

Choosing another style included in Guides could communicate something different.

Furthermore, any 3D part can be resized.

This step uses only one rectangular zone from the 3D Toolkit to highlight three different sized areas on the example machine.

Now you know how easy it is to use and customize 3D content!

Next we will summarize some top tips for making good guides...

You can use Guides for many purposes by adding 3D objects and then customizing them.

However, having too many 3D objects on one step can overwhelm an operator.

Keep your steps short!

Breakdown procedures into small, easily understood steps that are clear and concise.

Don't be afraid to make more steps.

The tether is a great way to draw attention to an area or an object but it isn't required on every step.

Use the tether if it makes sense to do so.

That's it for authoring tips.

Have fun and experiment to see what works best for you in your guides!

AlignmentStep.InstructionText:
To align HoloLens to the printed anchor:

1. Select 'Scan' button to begin alignment
2. Stand 2-feet from the printed anchor
3. Look at the printed anchor

CompletionStep.InstructionText:
This concludes the Example Guide.

Now go make your own!
